These phenomena can lead to individuals not intervening in situations where help is needed even when they are aware of the problem.  The bystander effect refers to the tendency for individuals to be less likely to help when there are more people present. This is often attributed to the assumption that someone else will take responsibility for providing assistance. Social loafing on the other hand is the phenomenon where individuals exert less effort when working in a group compared to working individually.
